author: JENNIFER EDER
title: Drug dealer used codenames to sell meth and cannabis
text:
Drug dealer used codenames to sell meth and cannabis JENNIFER EDER Last updated 18:23, February 7 2017 FAIRFAX NZ 
Charles Maru fielded requests for "garlic bread", which was code for cannabis, police say. 
A Blenheim man selling methamphetamine and cannabis by text message has been caught despite using various codenames for his product. 
Police said they first became aware Charles Wiremu Maru was selling drugs in September last year and began monitoring his text messages. 
The 36-year-old would sometimes text people to tell them he had drugs to sell, and sometimes they would text him to find out if he had a particular type of drug for sale. 
"Do you want a tin?" Maru asked an associate about 4.20pm on September 20, the police summary of facts said. 
The word tin, or tinny, was widely used to describe 1 to 2 grams of cannabis wrapped in tin foil, which usually sold for $20, the summary said. 
From there, codenames became more creative. 
About a week later, an associate messaged Maru saying he wanted a "tin". 
"I'll suz u ding and I'll get back asap", Maru replied. 
Police said the word "ding" was a reference to a tinny. 
On September 29, an associate asked for some "toast", which referred to cannabis, and another asked for some "puff", which referred to methamphetamine, police said. Ad Feedback 
Maru and the associate settled on a price of $550 for half a gram of methamphetamine. 
Later, the same associate asked if he could get a "Q", or a quarter gram of methamphetamine, police said. 
On October 2, Maru text messaged an associate to say he was trying to sell "ding". 
"Is da garlic bread a good size?" the associate asked. 
"Skunk," Maru replied. Skunk was a type of cannabis grown under indoor lights, police said. 
Maru sold cannabis and methamphetamine on eight more occasions during October using the words "ding" and "Q". 
He also used "pool que" and "chicken" in reference to methamphetamine. 
When spoken to by police, Maru admitted he was using codenames to sell cannabis and methamphetamine. 
He appeared at the Blenheim District Court on Tuesday, where he admitted six charges of offering to sell methamphetamine, and 10 of offering to sell cannabis. 
His lawyer Rob Harrison said the amount of drugs sold was minor compared to other drug dealers that came before the courts. 
Maru had struggled with addiction for years but had stopped using drugs since he was charged, Harrison said. 
He had arranged to see a drug and alcohol counsellor, and was considering entering a residential rehabilitation programme, Harrison said. 
Maru had cannabis-related charges in his criminal history but nothing involving methamphetamine. 
Judge David Ruth remanded him on bail to be sentenced on April 4. - The Marlborough Express
